Hi Adrian,

Interesting approach...  I have two remarks:

1) I find it a bi=
t odd that inside a class Stack, you find yourself creating
a brand new ins=
tance of Stack and passing it around, instead of just reusing
the same inst=
ance (I realize it's because JUnit creates a new instance
before each test,=
 but this doesn't strike me as optimal)

2) Your current implementation wil=
l break if a method gets renamed, which is
why, while TestNG supports direc=
t method dependencies with
@Test(dependsOnMethods), I highly recommend usin=
g group dependencies
instead:

class Stack {
  @Test(groups =3D "populate")=

  public void pushShouldPopulate() {
    ...
  }

  @Test(dependsOnGroups =
=3D "populate")
  public void popShouldReturnTopElement() {
    ...
  }
}

=
The advantage of this approach is that it is independent of method names
("=
refactoring safe"") and it captures the fact that any test method that
popu=
lates the stack is a valid prerequisite to testing pop().  In other
words, =
you can add more methods to the group "populate" and everything will
work a=
s long as all these methods leave the stack populated with at least
one ele=
ment.

Anyway, I'm glad to see test dependencies receive the attention they=
 deserve
:-)

-- 
C=E9dric

>   Welcome everyone,

ope that this is the right place to announce a novel

 not, please point us to the proper

>
> JExample is an extensions =
that introduces dependencies. But unlike eg
> TestNG, we go beyond mere dep=
endencies. We use
> dependencies to pass the "instance under test" from one=
 the test method to
> the next. If test B depends on A, the return value of=
 A
> can be used as B's fixture. And if A test fails, B and all other depen=
dees
> of A are skipped and marked as white. We show in an
> empirical stud=
y (accepted at the XP2008 conference) that JExample improves
> performance,=
 shortness of test methods, and defect
> localization.
>
> Let me give an e=
xample :)
>
> Testing a stack is not trivial, there is an intrinsic depende=
ncy between
> pushing and popping elements. An element can not be
> popped =
without pushing it first. Intrinsic dependencies are evil. If there
> is a =
bug in push, both push's and pop's test fail, even if
> there is no bug in =
pop! Therefore, we declare that testPop depends on the
> successful outcome=
 of testPush. When running the
> tests, the return value of testPush is use=
d as the fixture of testPop.
>
> @Test
> public Stack testPush() {
> Stack =
s =3D new Stack();
> s.push("Foo");
> assertEquals(1, s.size());
> return s=
;
> }
>
> @Test
> @Depends("testPush")
> public void testPop(Stack s) {
> s=
.pop("Foo");
> assertEquals(0, s.size());
> }
>
> Using JExample, each test=
 method is a comprehensive constructor that
> creates an example instance o=
f the unit under test. That is
> also why JExample is called JExample. The =
idea of example-driven testing is
> based on the work of Markus Gaelli.
